comments.author: Limor
comments.content:
I grew up in Israel and Amba may be my favorite condiment (well, a close second to horseradish). It's great on sandwiches (instead of mustard) and I also eat it with a simple Moroccan recipe that I make--  meatballs, sweet peas (canned), onions and powder Israeli chicken broth (by Osem). 

I tend to find it in specialty Israeli / Middle Eastern stores... there is usually a few in every major city. 

I am excited to try this recipe.

comments.author: Yael
comments.content: Homemade amba ,wow:) I like to add amba sometimes to salad dressings.

comments.author: Betty Ann @Mango_Queen
comments.content: It's my first time to see this recipe, but I was drawn to "Mango" soon as I saw it as a main ingredient. Delish! Thanks for sharing, Michael!

comments.author: bazina!
comments.content: MMM... in Hawai'i, we eat pickled mango off the ying yang.  It's a tad tart but sweet too.  We make it with vinegar, fresh (slightly under ripe) mangoes, and li hing mui powder.  It's a childhood favorite!

comments.author: Natalie
comments.content: They love pickled mango in Madagascar, too! In northwestern Mada they call it manga achard  and it's the same except for using green mangoes and adding some sliced onion to the lemon brine.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Lin hing mui powder! I just had to google that, and I'd estimate it will be less than a day before I own some! Sounds right up my alley. If you've had umeboshi plum, is the taste similar?

comments.author: torviewtoronto
comments.content: delicious post one of my favourite way to eat mangos pickled we call mango amba

comments.author: Emily Stevenson
comments.content:
This sounds like an awesome recipe! YUM!  Thanks for sharing. :)  I am a vegetarian, but my hubby and kids are not.  I always have to bring out the best dishes if I want to all of us to go meatless for a meal.  This recipe will be very popular I am sure!

I also blog about the meatless diet and energized life at www.thelivelyvegetarian.blogspot.com if you are interested.

Thanks again!

comments.author: AD
comments.content: Amba-Haldi is also the Gujarati (Indian) word for a fresh turmeric pickle.  Further, Amba is the Gujarati word for mango.  Indians love their own version of mango pickle - like Gor-Keri or Methiyu!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Wow! I know of various Indian mango pickles but didn't know the word came from Gujarat. I assume there is an ancient trade route story in there somewhere.

comments.author: Noam
comments.content: You can get it in any Israeli grocery store at major cities like Miami, New York, LA.

comments.author: Selina
comments.content: I'm Iraqi Jewish and growing up, umba was always on the table for our cultural dishes. I get mine from my local Turkish mini market. Love it. I'll give this recipe a go some day
